section.title: What are transactional updates?
section.para: To keep the base operating system stable and consistent, the &productname; (&productnameshort;) uses a read-only root file system. Therefore, you cannot perform direct changes to the root file system, for example, by using the zypper command. Instead, &productnameshort; introduces transactional updates that allow you to apply one or more changes to the root file system.

section.title: How do transactional updates work?
section.para: Each time you call the &tr-up; command to change your system—either to install a package, perform an update, or apply a patch—the following actions take place:

step.para: A new read-write snapshot is created from your current root file system, or from a snapshot that you specified.
All changes are applied (updates, patches or package installation).
The snapshot is switched back to read-only mode.
If the changes were applied successfully, the new root file system snapshot is set as default.
After rebooting, the system boots into the new snapshot.

listitem.para: They are atomic—the update is applied only if it completes successfully.
Changes are applied in a separate snapshot and so do not influence the running system.
Changes can easily be rolled back.

section.title: Environment within transactional-update command
section.para: Each time you run the &tr-up; command, the changes are performed in a separate snapshot, where some environment variables may have a different value, than in the shell you run the &tr-up; from. For example, the value of the PWD environment variable is not set to the directory you run the &tr-up; from, but it is set to /.

From within the new snapshot you cannot access the /var directory and this directory is also not included in the snapshot as described in . However, some directories are not included in the snapshot but are accessible from within the &tr-up; environment, for example, the /root directory.
